headline.main: Health Care for a Changing Work Force

docs.abstract: With 42 million independent workers in the United States, the Freelancers Union's health plan may be a model for the future.
docs.snippet: With 42 million independent workers in the United States, the Freelancers Union's health plan may be a model for the future.

docs.lead_paragraph: Big institutions are often slow to awaken to major social transformations. Microsoft was famously late to grasp the importance of the Internet. American auto manufacturers were slow to identify the demand for fuel-efficient cars. And today, the United States government is making a similar mistake: it still doesn't seem to recognize that Americans no longer work the way they used to.

headline.main: Health Care for a Changing Work Force

docs.abstract: With 42 million independent workers in the United States, the Freelancers Union's health plan may be a model for the future.
docs.snippet: With 42 million independent workers in the United States, the Freelancers Union's health plan may be a model for the future.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three senators asked Pfizer to detail their agreements to block prescriptions of generic versions of Lipitor, saying they were against the idea of drug makers manipulating the marketplace.

headline.seo: Senators Question Plan to Stall Generic Lipitor
headline.main: Senators Question Deals to Block Generic Lipitor
headline.print_headline: Senators Question Deals to Block Generic Lipitor

docs.abstract: Senators Max Baucus, Charles E Grassley and Herb Kohl ask Pfizer and five other health companies to detail their agreements to block prescriptions of generic versions of cholesterol drug Lipitor, calling it marketplace manipulation.
docs.snippet: Three senators asked Pfizer to detail their agreements to block prescriptions of generic versions of Lipitor, saying they were against the idea of drug makers manipulating the marketplace.

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City’s health commissioner is pushing an aggressive change in the city policy toward the virus that causes AIDS, saying his recommendation to doctors will reduce transmission.

headline.seo: To Stop AIDS, N.Y.C. Wants Drugs Given Sooner for H.I.V.
headline.main: Seeing Chance to End Spread of H.I.V., City’s Health Chief Pushes Earlier Drug Treatment
headline.print_headline: Seeing Chance to End Spread of H.I.V., City’s Health Chief Pushes Earlier Drug Treatment

docs.abstract: New York City Health Commissioner Dr Thomas Farley is pushing an aggressive change in the city's policy toward HIV, recommending that doctors begin to treat the virus as soon as it is diagnosed; says he believes effort will reduce transmission of HIV virus and could effectively eradicate new infections in New York City in his lifetime.
docs.snippet: New York City’s health commissioner is pushing an aggressive change in the city policy toward the virus that causes AIDS, saying his recommendation to doctors will reduce transmission.

docs.lead_paragraph: Good news, people! The former governor of Massachusetts really has told the truth at least once.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column weighs in on albatross around neck of Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney because of his track record of flip-flopping on multiple hot button issues; suggests that Romney be given a grace period with which to decide his one true opinion on any given topic, and then go forward from there.
docs.snippet: Good news, people! The former governor of Massachusetts really has told the truth at least once.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: India’s new private sector is increasingly powering the economy, but it chafes at what many companies say are labor laws that blunt hiring and stifle growth.

headline.seo: For India, Outsourcing Does the Job at Home, Too
headline.main: Outsourcing Giant Finds It Must Be Client, Too
headline.print_headline: Outsourcing Giant Finds It Must Be Client, Too

docs.abstract: India is known the world over as a prime innovator of outsourcing for foreign companies, but what is less well known is the extent to which Indian companies outsource jobs within their own country; the practice highlights a fundamental tension between India's socialist past and a new private sector that is increasingly powering the economy while chafing at what many companies say are laws so protective of workers that they blunt hiring and stifle growth (Series: India's Way).
docs.snippet: India’s new private sector is increasingly powering the economy, but it chafes at what many companies say are labor laws that blunt hiring and stifle growth.

byline.contributor: Sruthi Gottipati contributed reporting from Manesar, India, and Neha Thirani from Mumbai, India.

docs.lead_paragraph: Shahid R. Khan, who has an agreement to buy the Jacksonville Jaguars for $760 million, had coveted ownership of a professional sports franchise, particularly an N.F.L. team.

headline.seo: Shahid Khan Buys Jacksonville Jaguars and Realizes Dream
headline.main: Jaguars Buyer Had His Eye on Ownership of a Franchise

docs.abstract: Shahid R Khan, who has an agreement to buy the Jacksonville Jaguars for $760 million, had coveted ownership of a professional sports franchise, particularly an NFL team; his love of football was nurtured in college and his riches as an auto parts manufacturer made the dream possible.
docs.snippet: Shahid R. Khan, who has an agreement to buy the Jacksonville Jaguars for $760 million, had coveted ownership of a professional sports franchise, particularly an N.F.L. team.

headline.print_headline: His Last Snap Behind Him, Collins Has No Regrets
